user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemTake_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemTake_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    if (sem_wait(&impl->id) < 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CountSemTake_Impl:
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided function and related inline helper. There is no direct use of the Standard Library function memcmp anywhere in the shown code (the function only calls sem_wait and returns constants). The inline helper OS_ObjectIndexFromToken simply returns a numeric field (token->obj_idx) and contains no string operations. The only place that could conceivably hide a memcmp invocation is the macro call OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, whose definition was not provided; that macro could expand to code that performs comparisons (potentially using memcmp on null-terminated strings). Therefore the macro invocation line is flagged for investigation. All other lines in the provided code do not involve string comparisons or calls to memcmp and do not need further investigation for Rule 21.14 based on the supplied code.
